@@ -14,3 +20,47 @@ func GenerateMnemonic(entropySize int) (string, error) {
 	// Generate the actual mnemonic
 	return bip39.NewMnemonic(entropySeed[:])
 }
+
+// GenerateMnemonicWithCustomEntropy generates a BIP39 mnemonic using
+// user-provided entropy instead of computer PRNG
+func GenerateMnemonicWithCustomEntropy(io commands.IO) (string, error) {
+	// Display entropy advice
+	io.Println("")
+	io.Println("=== MANUAL ENTROPY GENERATION ===")
+	io.Println("")
+	io.Println("Provide at least 160 bits of entropy from a true random source:")
+	io.Println("- Dice: 38+ d20 rolls (e.g., 18 7 3 12 5 19 8 2 14 11...)")
+	io.Println("- Coins: 160+ flips (e.g., HTTHHTTHHHTTHHTHTTHHTHHT...)")
+	io.Println("- Cards: 31+ draws (e.g., 7H 2C KS 9D 4H JS QC 3S...)")
+	io.Println("- Other: keyboard mashing, environmental noise, etc.")
+	io.Println("")
+
+	// Get the entropy input
+	inputEntropy, err := io.GetString("Enter your entropy (any length, will be hashed with SHA-256):")
+	if err != nil {
+		return "", err
+	}
+
+	if len(inputEntropy) < 27 {
+		return "", fmt.Errorf("entropy too short (%d characters). Please provide at least 27 characters for 160-bit security", len(inputEntropy))
+	}
+
+	// Hash the input entropy to create deterministic seed
+	hashedEntropy := sha256.Sum256([]byte(inputEntropy))
+
+	// Show what we're using as entropy (first 16 bytes as hex)
+	io.Printf("\nDerived entropy (SHA-256): %x...\n", hashedEntropy[:16])
+	io.Printf("Input length: %d characters\n", len(inputEntropy))
+
+	// Confirm before proceeding
+	conf, err := io.GetConfirmation("Generate mnemonic from this entropy?")
comment.body:
When I press enter on the confirmation, it should be a "confirmation" by default, not derive to `false`, just a small thing that improves the ux, unless you want the user to be explicit here.

If you want the user to be explicit, then capitalize the `n` as the default option

comment.body:
I'm trying to figure out what value this tool adds for gnokey, that `GenerateMnemonicWithCustomEntropy` in gnokey already doesn't -- they both just take user input, validate it, and then derive the mnemonic from the input.


My expectation going into reading this code was that it was going to be interactive, and guide the user to generate entropy (ex. ask him to move the mouse, enter keys repeatedly...)

The only benefit I see is if I want to use this tool for something like Adena -- in which case it makes sense, but I would reuse as much of the gnokey helpers as possible, instead of rewriting them

issue.title: How to configure multi-node startup?
issue.body:
## Description
Hello, I want to launch multiple nodes. How should I configure them, and which parameters need to be modified? The documentation only provides a demo for starting a single node.

issue.title: `gnodev -txs-file=` should detect dependencies

pull_request.title: feat(gnolang): consume gas when we allocate
pull_request.body:
### Summary
This PR implements gas charging for memory allocations in the Gno virtual machine, providing better resource management

⚠️ High Impact Note: This change will significantly affect how we render and execute Gno programs, as memory allocations now consume gas. Operations that previously had predictable gas costs may now require substantially higher gas limits, especially for memory-intensive rendering operations.

### Changes Made

#### Core Implementation
- **Enhanced Allocator Structure**: Added `maxBytesUsed` tracking and `gasMeter` integration to the allocator
- **Gas Charging Logic**: Memory allocations now consume gas at a rate of 1 gas unit per byte allocated
- **Peak Memory Tracking**: Only charge gas when memory usage reaches a new peak, avoiding double-charging for temporary allocations

#### Key Features
- **Economic Memory Management**: Memory usage is now economically constrained through gas fees
- **GC Integration**: Works seamlessly with existing garbage collection mechanisms

#### Technical Details
```go
// New fields added to Allocator
maxBytesUsed int64        // Track peak memory usage
gasMeter     store.GasMeter // Integration with gas system

// Gas charging logic - only charge for new peaks
if alloc.bytes > alloc.maxBytesUsed {
    change := alloc.bytes - alloc.maxBytesUsed
    alloc.gasMeter.ConsumeGas(overflow.Mulp(change, GasCostPerByte), "memory allocation")
    alloc.maxBytesUsed = alloc.bytes
}
```

### Test Updates
Updated integration tests to reflect new gas consumption patterns:
- Basic operations: ~1-2K additional gas
- Package deployment: ~500 additional gas  
- Memory-intensive operations: Significant increases (GC test: 512K → 262M gas)


### Breaking Changes
⚠️ **Gas Requirements**: Existing transactions may require higher gas limits due to memory allocation costs.

@@ -1991,9 +1990,29 @@ func (m *Machine) PushFrameCall(cx *CallExpr, fv *FuncValue, recv TypedValue, is
 				return
 			}
 		}
-	} else { // top level function
-		// no switch
-		return
+	} else { // function without receiver
+		if pv.IsRealm() {
+			// A function without receiver (named or unnamed) in a realm.
+			// Borrow switch to where the function is declared,
+			// since there is no receiver.
+			// Neither cross nor didswitch.
+			pkgPath := pv.PkgPath
+			rlm = m.Store.GetPackageRealm(pkgPath)
+			m.Realm = rlm
+			// DO NOT set DidCrossing here. Make
+			// DidCrossing only happen upon explicit
+			// cross(fn)(...) calls and subsequent calls to
+			// crossing functions from the same realm, to
+			// avoid user confusion. Otherwise whether
+			// DidCrossing happened or not depends on where
+			// the receiver resides, which isn't explicit
+			// enough to avoid confusion.
+			//   fr.DidCrossing = true
+		} else {
+			// A function without receiver in a non-realm package.
+			// no switch
+			return
+		}
comment.body:
Yeah, IMO the issue this PR addresses is that FuncValue passed around can steal privileges from the host realm.
so what we do is to add them to the `ExceptionList`. thus, we will have:

- Explicit cross
- Soft cross to receiver's owner realm(where it's stored)
- Soft cross to FuncValue's origin realm(where it's declared)
- no cross to else's func.

pull_request.title: fix: compile regx before use
pull_request.body:
Because Compile() happens dynamically run-time, it can cause concurrent map writes: https://github.com/gnolang/gno/pull/4568

This PR fixes it by making sure the regexes we use at runtime are already compiled during init.

This improves efficiency by not requiring a map lookup each time.

issue.title: Repo structure and binaries' improvements

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Want to contribute? We recommend these issues.

issue.body:
**Please note that the comments should be read. The body of this issue is not yet updated with the latest decisions.**

This issue seeks to clarify concepts and suggest future updates, related to #1105, where I proposed a `gnosdk` space.

The `gno.land/cmd/gno` and `gnosdk` should focus on user experience, while the rest of `gno.land`, `gnosdk`, and `tm2` should showcase standalone binaries and minimalist libraries.

The main binary, `gno.land/cmd/gno`, should be the developers' go-to binary in the ecosystem, catering to both developers and non-developers. Considering `gno.land`'s significant role with github-style realms, IBC, and ICS features, it's fitting to house the ecosystem binary, `gno.land/cmd/gno`, here, even if it extends beyond `gno.land`.

`gnoland`, designed for production runtime management and daemon operation, should remain minimalist, focusing on node initiation and network joining, leaving extensive configuration and management tools to `gnosdk` or `gno` under a `node`/`genesis` subcommand.

The `fooland` binary, aligning with other cosmos chains, serves as a central hub, combining standalone libraries/binaries into one. Once established, the secondary binary, "gno," becomes necessary, allowing "fooland" to focus on unique features and enabling gnolang developers to use standard ecosystem tools.

I support including basic account management and client functionality in the `gno` binary, reducing the need for `gnokey`, except for demonstrating a minimal client for a new chain.

## Proposal for structural target:

In **bold**, the things that are not existing yet.

- `gno.land`
  - `pkg`
    - `gnoland`: a node app for gno.land
    - ...
  - `cmd`
    - `gnokey`: a standalone minimal client for gno.land
      - `query`, `maketx`, etc. (client functionality)
      - `list`, `create`, etc. (account management)
    - `gnoland`: a standalone minimal production node for gno.land
      - `start`
      - **`reset`** (WIP)
    - `gnoweb`: a standalone minimal production gnoweb for gno.land
    - **`gno`**: the main binary for the gno ecosystem (moved from `gnovm/cmd/`)
      - `test`, `build`, `doc`, etc.: Go-like commands for gno; **I suggest we switch from `gno.Machine` to `gnovm.Keeper`**
      - **`genesis`**: tools for manipulating the genesis of gno.land
      - **`node {backup,restore}`**: new place for gnotxport
      - **`node stats`,...**: other helpers related to node management
      - **`dev`**: an opinionated shortcut to run a single gnoland node + gnoweb in memory/disk
- `gnovm`
  - `pkg`
    - `gnolang`: current `gnolang/gno.Machine`
    - **`commands`**: composable CLI commands, equivalent of `tm2/keys/client`
  - `cmd`
    - **`gnolang`**: new binary with blockchain-less `gno.Machine` commands (most of today's `gno` binary)
- **`gnosdk`**
  - **`pkg`**
    - **`genesis`**: a library for manipulating the genesis
    - **`codegen`**: helpers for code generation in the gno ecosystem
  - **`cmd`**
    - **`fooland`**: a unified library with gnokey, gnoland, gnotxport, etc. to run a foo.land node or interact with it
      - **`query`, `maketx`**: gnokey's client functionality
      - **`list`, `create`**: gnokey's account management
      - **`node`**
        - **`start`**: start gnoland
        - **`txport`**: backup and restore functionality from gnotxport to gno node
        - **`genesis-flows-such-as-POS-coordination`**
      - **`web`**: gnoweb
      - **`faucet`**: gnofaucet
- `tm2`
  - `pkg`
    - ...

pull_request.title: fix: compile regx before use
pull_request.body:
Because Compile() happens dynamically run-time, it can cause concurrent map writes: https://github.com/gnolang/gno/pull/4568

This PR fixes it by making sure the regexes we use at runtime are already compiled during init.

This improves efficiency by not requiring a map lookup each time.

issue.title: gnovm/stdlibs/bytes: lots of time spent in runtime garbage collection than in running programs

labels.name: 🐞 bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

issue.body:
Investigating #3421, trying to run a single test takes close to 3 minutes. On profiling we can see more than 60 seconds spent in garbage collection

![pprof003](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/fb46d7f1-49b4-483a-a50b-223e777600ac)
![profile001](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f93888d4-651a-425a-a210-6e6700a9b3bb)

We need to figure out how to reduce the memory bloat and all the garbage collection cycles. Even for the beefiest servers, it is very rare to see programs spending most of their time in runtime.scanobject. This issue is going to require some more design considerations.

Kindly cc-ing @moul @thehowl @notJoon @jaekwon

+fini:

+}

issue.title: [OPS] FEATURE REQUEST: Pruning system - sign and forget
issue.body:
## Description

Currently, it is not possible to prune a node, all nodes store all blocks since block 1.

Once mainnet will arrive, there will be more transactions and storing all state since block 1 might create some storage issues on the nodes

There is multiple advantage about node pruning:

- reduce start-up time
- snapshots node are smaller, which make an easier and faster system to sync / recover / migrate a node.
- take less spaces on disks
- increase node performances

---

Another feature i would love to be implemented, which was already discuss once during a meeting with @jaekwon (long time ago) is the "Sign and forget" system.

Tendermint main bottleneck is disk usage, large chain must use NVMe for efficiency, an disks without pruning are growing really fast!

I believe a validator node don't require to store more than 1 block in memory, only the latest state should be required to store.

This feature i believe would increase BY A LOT performances, because we could almost get rid of disk usage and do everything in memory. If it's not done by code, it could be done by putting the `data/` dir into a `tmpfs` which is a in-memory file system.

FYI: On injective, with a ~1s block time, and the amount for txs, there is no possiblity to set the pruning because it cause a lot of block miss signature, and node is growing to couple hundreads of Gb in couple days...
A pruning from a pruned snapshot node is require every 1-2 week.

Of course, we might not have the same amount of txs from day 1, but if we start to have oracle writing in gno.land on every blocks, we could have node storage issues faster than we can expect.

cc: @moul @zivkovicmilos @gnolang/devops wdyt ?

ps: this issue will be mentioned in my gnops.io article i'm writing about snapshots node.

+
+// TestVMKeeperDeterminism tests that multiple runs of the same operations
+// produce the same app hash, ensuring deterministic behavior.
+// See #4580 for context.
+func TestVMKeeperDeterminism(t *testing.T) {
+	// Determine number of runs based on -short flag
+	numRuns := 50
+	if testing.Short() {
+		numRuns = 5
+	}
+
+	runOperations := func() (string, error) {
+		env := setupTestEnv()
+		ctx := env.vmk.MakeGnoTransactionStore(env.ctx)
+
+		caller := crypto.AddressFromPreimage([]byte("caller"))
+		acc := env.acck.NewAccountWithAddress(ctx, caller)
+		env.acck.SetAccount(ctx, acc)
+
+		// Give enough coins for package creation
+		env.bankk.SetCoins(ctx, caller, std.MustParseCoins(ugnot.ValueString(100_000_000)))
+
+		// Create realms with names designed to have different map iteration orders
+		realms := []string{
+			"gno.land/r/test/realm_aaa",
+			"gno.land/r/test/realm_zzz",
+			"gno.land/r/test/realm_mmm",
+			"gno.land/r/test/realm_001",
+			"gno.land/r/test/realm_999",
+			"gno.land/r/test/realm_abc",
+			"gno.land/r/test/realm_xyz",
+			"gno.land/r/test/realm_123",
+			"gno.land/r/test/realm_789",
+			"gno.land/r/test/realm_def",
+		}
+
+		// Create each realm
+		for i, realmPath := range realms {
+			files := []*std.MemFile{
+				{Name: "gnomod.toml", Body: gnolang.GenGnoModLatest(realmPath)},
+				{
+					Name: "realm.gno",
+					Body: fmt.Sprintf(`package %s
+
+var storage []string
+
+func UpdateStorage(cur realm, n int) {
+	// Force storage growth based on realm index
+	for i := 0; i < n+%d*100; i++ {
+		storage = append(storage, "data_data_data_data")
+	}
+}`, path.Base(realmPath), i),
+				},
+			}
+			msg := NewMsgAddPackage(caller, realmPath, files)
+			err := env.vmk.AddPackage(ctx, msg)
+			require.NoError(t, err)
+		}
+
+		// Create master realm
+		masterPath := "gno.land/r/test/master"
+
+		// Build imports and calls dynamically
+		imports := ""
+		calls := ""
+		for _, realmPath := range realms {
+			alias := path.Base(realmPath)
+			imports += fmt.Sprintf("\t%s \"%s\"\n", alias, realmPath)
+			calls += fmt.Sprintf("\t%s.UpdateStorage(cross, 500)\n", alias)
+		}
+
+		masterCode := fmt.Sprintf(`package master
+
+import (
+%s)
+
+func UpdateAll(cur realm) {
+%s}`, imports, calls)
+
+		masterFiles := []*std.MemFile{
+			{Name: "gnomod.toml", Body: gnolang.GenGnoModLatest(masterPath)},
+			{Name: "master.gno", Body: masterCode},
+		}
+		msg := NewMsgAddPackage(caller, masterPath, masterFiles)
+		err := env.vmk.AddPackage(ctx, msg)
+		require.NoError(t, err)
+
+		// Call with limited deposit to force errors in processStorageDeposit
+		// The error will depend on which realms get processed first
+		callMsg := NewMsgCall(caller, std.Coins{}, masterPath, "UpdateAll", []string{})
+		callMsg.MaxDeposit = std.MustParseCoins(ugnot.ValueString(20_000_000))
+
+		// Capture the error - it should vary based on iteration order
+		_, err = env.vmk.Call(ctx, callMsg)
+
+		env.vmk.CommitGnoTransactionStore(ctx)
+
+		// Return error string which should vary with iteration order
+		if err != nil {
+			return err.Error(), err
+		}
+		return "no_error", nil
+	}
+
+	// Track first error message as baseline
+	firstMsg, _ := runOperations()
+
+	// Check subsequent runs for differences
+	for i := 1; i < numRuns; i++ {
+		errMsg, _ := runOperations()
+
+		// Fail immediately if we find a different error message
+		if errMsg != firstMsg {
+			t.Logf("Non-determinism detected at run %d!", i+1)
+			t.Logf("First error: %s", firstMsg)
+			t.Logf("Different error at run %d: %s", i+1, errMsg)
+			t.Fatalf("TEST CORRECTLY FAILED: VM Keeper operations are non-deterministic without the sorting fix in PR #4580")
+		}
+
+		// Force GC and allocations to change runtime state
+		if i%10 == 0 {
+			runtime.GC()
+			// Create some allocations to change heap state
+			temp := make([]map[string]int, 100)
+			for j := range temp {
+				temp[j] = make(map[string]int)
+				temp[j]["key"] = j
+			}
+		}
comment.body:
> "maketx run" providing a lambda to a DAO, and in another transaction, the DAO executes. It works if you keep the node running, but not if you restart the node between two txs

Do we have more information about this issue? It seems the state may not have been persisted properly. Which part of PR4422 addresses this?

Is the following case similar to what you described?

I added gnoland stop and gnoland start between each message run, and it appears to work fine — I couldn't reproduce the issue.

https://github.com/gnolang/gno/blob/de4b5b56c60126373ec0702234c196fdae365a0b/gno.land/pkg/integration/testdata/update_storage_params.txtar#L22

https://github.com/gnolang/gno/blob/de4b5b56c60126373ec0702234c196fdae365a0b/gno.land/pkg/integration/testdata/update_storage_params.txtar#L31

issue.title: feat(gnovm): custom go parser for gas counting and nesting limits #2

labels.name: :package: :robot: gnovm
labels.description: Issues or PRs gnovm related

issue.body:
This is a refreshed attempt similar to #4027.

Import the Go parser from the standard library. We will then customize it to allow gas estimation during parsing, and also put hard limits on nesting for security purposes.

A Makefile to facilitate the import from the standard library and maintaining the custom patch is provided.

More to come in subsequent changes.

pull_request.title: feat(gnovm): custom go parser for gas counting and nesting limits #2
pull_request.body:
This is a refreshed attempt similar to #4027.

Import the Go parser from the standard library. We will then customize it to allow gas estimation during parsing, and also put hard limits on nesting for security purposes.

A Makefile to facilitate the import from the standard library and maintaining the custom patch is provided.

More to come in subsequent changes.

+
+// TestVMKeeperDeterminism tests that multiple runs of the same operations
+// produce the same app hash, ensuring deterministic behavior.
+// See #4580 for context.
+func TestVMKeeperDeterminism(t *testing.T) {
+	// Determine number of runs based on -short flag
+	numRuns := 50
+	if testing.Short() {
+		numRuns = 5
+	}
+
+	runOperations := func() (string, error) {
+		env := setupTestEnv()
+		ctx := env.vmk.MakeGnoTransactionStore(env.ctx)
+
+		caller := crypto.AddressFromPreimage([]byte("caller"))
+		acc := env.acck.NewAccountWithAddress(ctx, caller)
+		env.acck.SetAccount(ctx, acc)
+
+		// Give enough coins for package creation
+		env.bankk.SetCoins(ctx, caller, std.MustParseCoins(ugnot.ValueString(100_000_000)))
+
+		// Create realms with names designed to have different map iteration orders
+		realms := []string{
+			"gno.land/r/test/realm_aaa",
+			"gno.land/r/test/realm_zzz",
+			"gno.land/r/test/realm_mmm",
+			"gno.land/r/test/realm_001",
+			"gno.land/r/test/realm_999",
+			"gno.land/r/test/realm_abc",
+			"gno.land/r/test/realm_xyz",
+			"gno.land/r/test/realm_123",
+			"gno.land/r/test/realm_789",
+			"gno.land/r/test/realm_def",
+		}
+
+		// Create each realm
+		for i, realmPath := range realms {
+			files := []*std.MemFile{
+				{Name: "gnomod.toml", Body: gnolang.GenGnoModLatest(realmPath)},
+				{
+					Name: "realm.gno",
+					Body: fmt.Sprintf(`package %s
+
+var storage []string
+
+func UpdateStorage(cur realm, n int) {
+	// Force storage growth based on realm index
+	for i := 0; i < n+%d*100; i++ {
+		storage = append(storage, "data_data_data_data")
+	}
+}`, path.Base(realmPath), i),
+				},
+			}
+			msg := NewMsgAddPackage(caller, realmPath, files)
+			err := env.vmk.AddPackage(ctx, msg)
+			require.NoError(t, err)
+		}
+
+		// Create master realm
+		masterPath := "gno.land/r/test/master"
+
+		// Build imports and calls dynamically
+		imports := ""
+		calls := ""
+		for _, realmPath := range realms {
+			alias := path.Base(realmPath)
+			imports += fmt.Sprintf("\t%s \"%s\"\n", alias, realmPath)
+			calls += fmt.Sprintf("\t%s.UpdateStorage(cross, 500)\n", alias)
+		}
+
+		masterCode := fmt.Sprintf(`package master
+
+import (
+%s)
+
+func UpdateAll(cur realm) {
+%s}`, imports, calls)
+
+		masterFiles := []*std.MemFile{
+			{Name: "gnomod.toml", Body: gnolang.GenGnoModLatest(masterPath)},
+			{Name: "master.gno", Body: masterCode},
+		}
+		msg := NewMsgAddPackage(caller, masterPath, masterFiles)
+		err := env.vmk.AddPackage(ctx, msg)
+		require.NoError(t, err)
+
+		// Call with limited deposit to force errors in processStorageDeposit
+		// The error will depend on which realms get processed first
+		callMsg := NewMsgCall(caller, std.Coins{}, masterPath, "UpdateAll", []string{})
+		callMsg.MaxDeposit = std.MustParseCoins(ugnot.ValueString(20_000_000))
+
+		// Capture the error - it should vary based on iteration order
+		_, err = env.vmk.Call(ctx, callMsg)
+
+		env.vmk.CommitGnoTransactionStore(ctx)
+
+		// Return error string which should vary with iteration order
+		if err != nil {
+			return err.Error(), err
+		}
+		return "no_error", nil
+	}
+
+	// Track first error message as baseline
+	firstMsg, _ := runOperations()
+
+	// Check subsequent runs for differences
+	for i := 1; i < numRuns; i++ {
+		errMsg, _ := runOperations()
+
+		// Fail immediately if we find a different error message
+		if errMsg != firstMsg {
+			t.Logf("Non-determinism detected at run %d!", i+1)
+			t.Logf("First error: %s", firstMsg)
+			t.Logf("Different error at run %d: %s", i+1, errMsg)
+			t.Fatalf("TEST CORRECTLY FAILED: VM Keeper operations are non-deterministic without the sorting fix in PR #4580")
+		}
+
+		// Force GC and allocations to change runtime state
+		if i%10 == 0 {
+			runtime.GC()
+			// Create some allocations to change heap state
+			temp := make([]map[string]int, 100)
+			for j := range temp {
+				temp[j] = make(map[string]int)
+				temp[j]["key"] = j
+			}
+		}
comment.body:
I'm not sure 100%, but there is definitely something that can happen with fresh memory. For instance, the "maketx run" providing a lambda to a DAO, and in another transaction, the DAO executes. It works if you keep the node running, but not if you restart the node between two txs. This issue is currently being addressed (by prevention) in #4422.
It "appears" to work, but it actually doesn't due to memory coincidence.

pull_request.title: feat(example): refactor p/demo/blog
pull_request.body:
This PR is linked to the https://github.com/gnolang/gno/issues/4088 for scratching the old `/p/demo/blog` to make it better but still have it be compatible with the `gnoblo-cli`.

This is currently in `/p/lou/blog` as to start with a completely fresh package, the git diff is nicer to read this way.

These are the features:

Base:
- [x] Blog rendering with use of `mux` 
- [x] Filtering of tags through query --> `:tag/<tagname>`
- [x] Sorting alphabetically --> `?sort=alpha&order=asc`
- [x] Sorting from last updated --> `?sort=update&order=asc`


<details>
<summary>Added/modified:</summary>

- [x] Listing of all tags
    - [x] Add sorting options
    - [x] Number of posts
- [x] Listing of all authors
    - [x] Add sorting options
    - [x]  Number of posts
- [x] Listing in time ranges (start – end)  --> `?start=<time>&end=<time>`
    - [x] time.RFC3339, // rfc3339 format
    - [x] "2006-01-02", // date only
    - [x] "2006-01",    // year and month
    - [x] "2006",       // year only
- [x] Filtering of authors like it has already been done for tags (through query) --> `:author/<authorname>`
- [x] Toggle grid and list mode for Rendering (using gno-columns) --> `?mode=grid` or `?mode=list`
- [x] Adding pagination
- [x] Updating comments based on comment ID
- [x] Switching to `seq.id` as indexes
- [x] Improve error handling and messages throughout the package.
- [x] Pinning comments
- [x] Resolve users via `r/sys/users` registry.

</details>

<details>
<summary>Further (not mentioned in issue):</summary>

- [x] Filtering of commenters like it has already been done for tags (through query) --> `:commenter/<commentername>`
- [x] Sorting from most/least recent (for **posts** and **filters**) --> `?sort=recent&order=asc`
- [x] Toggle time format -- **Is it necessary?**
- [x] Add likes to comments
- [x] Add replies to comments
- [x] Add likes to posts -- **Is it necessary?**
- [x] `Mention` method to simulate a link to a specific author/ commenter (will link to :author or :commenter)
- [x] Make sorting/toggling options customizable (to disable/ or select)
- [x] Add a customizable option for rendering previews (at home, to add actions)
- [ ] Add tests
    - [x] Base of testings with uassert and urequire
    - [ ] For all scenarios
- [x] Add moderation
    - [x] Formatting, checking user validity and resolving
    - [x] Assert users
    - [x] Try using authorizable package
- [x] Fix total replies for comments size + reply id are relative to comments
- [ ] Add more documentation
    - [ ] More doc.gno
    - [ ] Add comments
    - [ ] Document customisation of rendering
    - [ ] Document custom of toggling/sort headers
 - [x] Add realm example for the use of the package

</details>

Package created to support:
- https://github.com/gnolang/gno/pull/4477

review.body:
TL;DR:
-  These constraints are the ideal default we are seeking for V1.
-  GovDAO can bypass them.
-  GovDAO can set a new controller, allowing us to create a "premium name registration DAO."
-  The anti-squatting system will unlock V2, which will eliminate this limitation.

---

We cannot remove the V1 limitations (3 digits) until we have the V2 system, which relies on the anti-squatting system.

Three-digit-ending names are considered non-premium enough to pose no market risk. If you recall, that's what discussed in the past; they follow the same principle, simply printing a `#`, e.g., `foobar#123`.

Once we have the anti-squatting system in place, we can lift this limitation, which is our goal. For now, people must permissionlessly obtain usernames by adhering to these rules or expect GovDAO to bypass this limit. Thus, we can envision GovDAO creating premium usernames immediately and even establishing a dedicated "name registration DAO" to manually manage the anti-squatting process, potentially using methods like KYC checks.

pull_request.title: chore: update username registration rules
pull_request.body:
## Description

This PR drops the following rule from the namespace registration:
> Usernames should end with three numbers.

It took me ~15mins to figure out why I couldn't register any of these seemingly normal usernames:
- zmilos
- zmil0s
- zivkovicmilos0

Original criteria is here: https://github.com/gnolang/gno/issues/2827

Additionally, I've also added better valid case test support, because the previous valid "tests" were embarrassing

milestone.title: 🚀 Mainnet beta launch
milestone.description:
**Main Milestone - We're On It! 🚧**

Hey all! We're right in the thick of our "main" milestone. It's not just a label; it's the heart of what we're currently pouring our energies into. And, let's be honest, it's both exciting and challenging at the same time!

🙌 **Here's how you can jump in:**
1. Take a peek at the open issues and PRs tied to this milestone.
2. Got an idea, a hunch, or even a gut feeling? Share it! Every perspective counts.
3. Chime into the discussions. The more, the merrier, and two heads (or ten) are always better than one.

This milestone is a journey, and every bit of effort, feedback, and camaraderie counts. Let's roll up our sleeves, maybe grab some coffee (or tea!), and push through this together. Cheers to making progress! 🎉

performed_via_github_app.name: Codecov
performed_via_github_app.description:
Codecov provides highly integrated tools to group, merge, archive and compare coverage reports. Whether your team is comparing changes in a pull request or reviewing a single commit, Codecov will improve the code review workflow and quality.

## Code coverage done right.®

1. Upload coverage reports from your CI builds.
2. Codecov merges all builds and languages into one beautiful coherent report.
3. Get commit statuses, pull request comments and coverage overlay via our browser extension.

When Codecov merges your uploads it keeps track of the CI provider (inc. build details) and user specified context, e.g. `#unittest` ~ `#smoketest` or `#oldcode` ~ `#newcode`. You can track the `#unittest` coverage independently of other groups. [Learn more here](
http://docs.codecov.io/docs/flags)

Through **Codecov's Browser Extension** reports overlay directly in GitHub UI to assist in code review in [Chrome](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/codecov/gedikamndpbemklijjkncpnolildpbgo) or Firefox (https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/codecov/)

*Highly detailed* **pull request comments** and *customizable* **commit statuses** will improve your team's workflow and code coverage incrementally.

**File backed configuration** all through the `codecov.yml`. 

## FAQ
- Do you **merge multiple uploads** to the same commit? **Yes**
- Do you **support multiple languages** in the same project? **Yes**
- Can you **group coverage reports** by project and/or test type? **Yes**
- How does **pricing** work? Only paid users can view reports and post statuses/comments.

commits.message: chore(keeper): remove debug print in keeper (#4582) Remove a debug print that appeared in `gnodev` and probably in `gnoland`.

fix(keeper): realm diff iteration, make it deterministic by sorting path (#4580)

Fix the nondeterministic issue that might be introduced by #4281
(storage deposit). The `processStorageDeposit` function iterates over a
map, which can lead to nondeterministic behavior since maps themselves
are nondeterministic. Although not optimal, the fix is to sort the realm
path before iterating.

Co-authored-by: Manfred Touron <94029+moul@users.noreply.github.com>

issue.title: ci(goreleaser): include tests/stdlibs
issue.body: #4563 added these directories to the dockerfiles, but they also need to be added to the goreleaser config. this is why the master CI for goreleaser is failing.

comment.body:
> @thehowl we did some cross text on Docker images last week and actually these files appears not needed anymore, are they?

They should be needed. The VMKeeper on chain performs type-checking using that directory:

https://github.com/gnolang/gno/blob/ce727711bd6814a49cae1b401a03109fcbe0dc2a/gno.land/pkg/sdk/vm/keeper.go

It's weird if it doesn't complain.

Given that they are not published, I think the goal is testing if building of binaries / docker images actually works

comment.body:
release --clean --nightly was used for a reason.

What we are currently doing is a release not from a tag but from a branch although it is master.
AFAIK the only way to release and perform all the steps avoiding to create a tag is using --nightly.

release --clean --snapshot will not push the docker images
